Context:
Program Name: Business Administration – Marketing
Code: B158
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters in-class, 2 semesters work experience)
Starting Months: January, September
Location: St. James Campus
Experiential Learning: Work Experience (Co-op or Internship) Required
Program Description: The Business Administration - Marketing program prepares students for careers in marketing, with a focus on hands-on learning opportunities and industry partnerships, as well as digital marketing courses, international marketing courses, marketing research courses, and marketing strategy courses. Students will be able to identify their target market and develop an integrated marketing communication strategy upon completion of the program.

Context:
* The Business Administration - Marketing program at George Brown College involves identifying target markets, creating marketing communication strategies, conducting market research, evaluating international marketing opportunities, and creating marketing plans that include objectives, marketing mix, strategies, budgets, and evaluation criteria.
* Students can participate in extracurricular activities such as the Ontario Colleges Marketing Competition, Vanier BDC Case Challenge, Enactus George Brown, Speed mentoring event, and Great Canadian Sales Competition.
* The Centre for Business at George Brown College has fourteen programs accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), including the Advanced diploma and diploma programs in Accounting and Finance, Human Resources, Management, and Marketing and the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program in Accounting and Finance.
* The program requires the successful completion of two semesters of work experience to graduate, which can be co-op or internship experiences. George Brown works with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities, and students are encouraged to pursue self-directed industry work experience opportunities as well.
* Field education opportunities at the Centre for Business include real world challenges and clients.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – Marketing Program (with work experience) B158 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Centre for Business at George Brown College offers a marketing program (B158) with included memberships to the Canadian Marketing Association (CMA) and Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB). CMA membership includes access to live and online events, professional development opportunities, resources and guides, networking opportunities, and exclusive access to CMA NXT. IAB membership offers student volunteer and networking opportunities for marquee events, members-only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, and global certification and custom workshops.

Graduates from the marketing program have found careers in various sectors such as advertising agencies, consulting firms, telecommunications and media, digital marketing, retailers, banks and financial institutions, government, not-for-profit organizations, and small businesses. Career options include marketing coordinator, account executive, product manager, social media coordinator, digital marketing manager, media planner or media buyer, market researcher, event marketer, sales account manager, web content manager, and small business owner.

Additional future study opportunities at George Brown College include the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Digital Marketing) Program B312, Sport and Event Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B400, Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406, Strategic Relationship Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B409, and Marketing Management – Digital Media Program (Postgraduate) B433.

To graduate from the marketing program, students need to complete 38 courses: 31 mandatory courses, 4 Business electives, 3 General Education electives, and 2 Work Experience terms (which can be co-op, internship, simulation or other forms).

Context:
The text describes the requirements for completing a program at the college, possibly a business or communication-related program. Here are the key factual points extracted from the text:

1. Work Experience: The college offers various types of work experiences including co-op, internship, simulation, consulting, or research projects. Some students may need to take prerequisite courses before progressing to certain work experience terms, and these courses do not count toward graduation requirements.
2. Placement Tests: Students may be required to take placement tests to determine which courses they need to take before progressing in their program.
3. General Education Courses: Students must complete three general education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities, or Science and Technology.
4. Failed or Dropped Courses: Students must make up any failed or dropped courses before they are eligible to graduate. Some of these courses may be offered during the day, while others are available through Continuing Education. Students should check with the business office staff to ensure that the Continuing Education courses are equivalent to those in the full-time program.
5. Course Listings: The text provides a list of courses offered in Semesters 1, 2, and 3, along with their prerequisites. Some courses have multiple prerequisites or require specific general education electives.
6. Business Concepts I (BUS 1038), Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000), Business Computer Applications I (COMP 1010), Principles of Marketing I (MARK 1020), Marketing Today (MARK 1046), Mathematics for Business & Management (MATH 1008), Principles of Accounting (ACCT 1036), Professional Communication I (COMM 1034), Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1115), Principles of Marketing II (MARK 2049), Human Skills (CMMK 1087), Mathematical Analysis for Marketers (MATH 1131)
7. Students can select one general education elective in Semester 2.

Overall, the text provides a detailed overview of the requirements and course offerings for completing a program at the college.

- CMMK 1114, COMM 1034, CMMK 1120, CMMK 1127

Courses offered in Semesters 3 to 6 include:
- Marketing courses: MARK 1055, MARK 1002, MARK 1020, MARK 2033, MARK 2049, MARK 2054, MARK 2063, MARK 2065, MARK 2069, MARK 2079, MARK 3017

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in the Business and Marketing program at the college. Here's a list of the courses mentioned along with their codes:

- COMM 1034: The Business Media in Canada, Talking Business, Retail Marketing, Advanced Sales Skills, MGMT 1034
- ACCT 2031: Managerial Accounting
- BUS 1044: Business Law
- MARK 2061: Applied Marketing Research, Case Based Approach to Marketing Strategies, Marketing Financial Services
- MGMT 2037: Retail Management, Shopper Research

The text also includes the program learning outcomes for the graduates of this program. These outcomes include:

- Develop a marketing plan that will meet the needs or goals of a business or organization.
- Develop an integrated marketing communication plan for marketing of a product, concept, good, or service based on an identified market need or target.
- Determine strategies for the development of new and/or modified marketing concepts, products, goods, and/or services that respond to evolving market needs.
- Determine strategies for the efficient and effective placement/distribution of a product, good, and/or service that respond to an evolving market.
- Determine the impact of using different marketing strategies for a product, concept, good and/or service, on the finances, return on investment (ROI), and business goals of an organization.
- Analyze the viability of a concept, product, good, and/or service in local, national or global markets.
- Conduct market research to provide information needed to make marketing decisions.
- Communicate marketing information persuasively and accurately in oral, written, graphic and interactive media formats.
- Plan, prepare and deliver an effective sales presentation or pitch to address the needs of the client.
- Develop strategies with clients, customers, consumers, co-workers, supervisors, and others to maintain and grow working relationships.
- Develop learning and development strategies to enhance professional growth in the field.
- Apply entrepreneurial strategies to identify and respond to new career opportunities that might include contract employment, and self-employment initiatives.
